conclusion: Analyze the p-V diagram to understand the process from state A to state B to state C.
The image shows a p-V diagram with state A at 3 × 10^5 Pa and 0.002 m^3, state B at a lower pressure, and state C at a lower volume than state B.
Identify key states in the p-V diagram: State A, State B, and State C.
State A has a known temperature of 27°C, equivalent to 300 K.
State A has a pressure of 3 × 10^5 Pa and a volume of approximately 0.002 m^3.
The process from state A to state B is isothermal, so the temperature remains constant at 300 K.
Use the ideal gas equation to find the volume at state B using the volume ratio: \( \frac{V_A}{V_B} = \frac{p_B}{p_A} \).
For the isobaric process from state B to state C, the pressure remains constant at 2 × 10^5 Pa.
Apply the ideal gas equation to find the temperature at state B: \( T_B = \frac{p_B \times V_B}{R} \).
Calculate the temperature at state B: \( T_B = \frac{2 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \times 0.003 \, \text{m}^3}{R} = 600 \, \text{K} \).
